Darvadstrocel was only indicated in patients without active CD and without presence of anorectal abscess. Local injection of darvadstrocel was carried out as a standardized procedure under general anesthesia including single-shot antibiotic prophylaxis, removal of seton drainage, fistula curettage, closure of the internal openings and local stem cell injection. Data collection focusing on healing rates, occurrence of abscess and follow-up was carried out on a regular basis of quality control and patient care. Data were retrospectively analyzed. Between July 2018 and January 2021, a total of 12 patients (6 women, 6 men) with a mean age of 42.5 (range of 26 to 61) years underwent SCT. All patients had a minimum of 1 complex fistula, including patients with 2 complex fistulas in 58.3 % (7/12). Two of the 12 patients had horse-shoe fistula and 3 had one complex fistula. According to Parks classification, the majority of fistulas were trans-sphincteric (76 %) or supra-sphincteric (14 %). All patients underwent removal of seton, fistula curettage, trans-anal closure of internal opening by suture (11/12) or mucosal flap (1/12) and stem cell injection. At a mean follow-up of 14.3 (range of 3 to 30) months, a healing rate was documented in 66.7 % (8/12); mean duration to achieve healing was 12 (range of 6 to 30) weeks. Within follow-up, 4 patients required re-operation due to perianal abscess (33.3 %). Focusing on patients with a minimum follow-up of 12 months (6/12) or 24 months (4/12), long-term healing rates were 66.7 % (4/6) and 50.0 % (2/4), respectively. The authors concluded that findings of this single-center experience were promising but limited due to the small number of patients (n = 12) and the retrospective analysis. These researchers stated that further inter-disciplinary efforts including controlled studies are needed to determine the definite role of SCT for the treatment of complex anal fistula in CD. Colombo et al (2022) noted that 30 % to 70 % of patients with CD may develop perianal fistulas during their lifetime. The medical and surgical management of this complication is challenging, and its treatment still gives unsatisfactory results. However, recent studies on ADSCs have proven their anti-inflammatory and immuno-modulatory potential, representing a new promising approach in the treatment of such stubborn disease. These investigators reported their initial experience with t3 patients who had recurrent perianal CD treated with local infiltration of stem cell darvadstrocel (Alofisel). All subjects had a long history of perianal disease refractory to multiple medical and surgical treatments. The pre-operative work-up included trans-perineal ultrasound (TP-US), pelvic MRI, and colonoscopy that ruled out active proctitis in all the patients. The post-treatment follow-up included clinical assessment at 1, 3, and 6 months with repeated MRI and TP-US at 6 months. At 6 months, 2 patients had a clinical response despite radiological persistence of fistula tracts, while 1 patient presented perianal fistula recurrence complicated by perianal abscess. Th authors concluded that although their experience was limited to 3 patients and a short follow-up, these findings confirmed that darvadstrocel injection was a safe procedure, with a good clinical response in most of the patients, but that it apparently had no effect on the anatomical modification of the fistula tracts. Moreover, these researchers stated that further studies with long-term results and rigorous assessment of anatomical lesions, are still needed to support these promising findings. Garcia-Olmo et al (2022) noted that darvadstrocel is an expanded allogeneic ADSCs for the treatment of CPFs in patients with CD. Safety and effectiveness outcomes from the clinical trial known as "Adipose derived mesenchymal stem cells for induction fistulizing Crohn's disease," or ADMIRE-CD (NCT01541579), from up to 52 weeks post-treatment were previously reported. These investigators reported the outcomes from an extended 104-week follow-up. This study extension was carried out in multiple hospitals across 7 European countries and Israel. A total of 40 patients entered the extended follow-up period: 25 patients in the darvadstrocel treatment group and 15 in the control group. Darvadstrocel or saline solution (control group) was administered once, locally, after fistula tract curettage and internal opening closure (with previous seton placement). All patients were permitted to continue ongoing medical treatments for fistulas. Treatment-emergent serious AEs were recorded through week 104. Clinical remission, defined as closure of all treated external openings that were draining at baseline despite gentle finger compression, was assessed at week 104. Of 40 patients, 37 completed the extended follow-up. Through week 104, 7 treatment-emergent serious AEs were reported, of which 4 occurred between weeks 52 and 104. At week 104, clinical remission was reported in 14/25 (56 %) patients in the darvadstrocel group and 6/15 (40 %) patients in the control group. The authors concluded that darvadstrocel was well-tolerated and clinical remission after treatment with darvadstrocel may be sustained for up to 104 weeks in patients with perianal fistulizing CD. The authors stated that this study had several drawbacks. First, at the time of the ADMIRE-CD protocol amendment, many patients had already completed the 52-week follow-up and had left the study; hence, they could not participate in this extended follow-up period to 104 weeks, and the relatively small sample size (n = 40) was a drawback of this study. Second, there was an imbalance in the number of patients in this extension study who were treated with darvadstrocel versus those in the control group (n = 25 versus n = 15, respectively), which could lead to potential bias in the analyses. Third, the lack of MRI examination at the end of the 104-week follow-up, hence combined remission rates (which included both clinical remission and absence of collections of greater than 2 cm diameter, confirmed by MRI) could not be determined (as previously reported for modified ITT population at weeks 24 and 52). It was anticipated that some of these drawbacks will be addressed by the ongoing INSPIRE global registry, which was set up to capture real-world safety and effectiveness data on a large number of patients with CPFs in CD treated with darvadstrocel and followed-up for over 36 months. Panes et al (2022) stated that the effectiveness of a single administration of darvadstrocel (expanded allogeneic ADSCs) for treating CPFs in patients with CD was demonstrated in a randomized, double-blind trial (ADMIRE-CD [Adipose Derived Mesenchymal Remission in Perianal Fistulizing Crohn\'s Disease] trial). The current chart review study (INSPECT [A retrospective chart review study evaluatINg the longer-term effectiveneSs of darvadstrocel in PatiEnts who CompleTed ADMIRE-CD]) evaluated the longer-term safety and effectiveness of darvadstrocel. Eligible patients had completed at least 52 weeks in the ADMIRE-CD trial. Data on clinical remission and fistula relapse outcomes were collected retrospectively at 104 and 156 weeks after treatment. AEs of special interest (tumorigenicity and ectopic tissue formation) were collected up to 208 weeks after treatment. A total of 89 patients were included (43 darvadstrocel patients, 46 control subjects). At 52-, 104-, and 156-week post-treatment, clinical remission was observed in 29 (67.4 %) of 43, 23 (53.5 %) of 43, and 23 (53.5% ) of 43 darvadstrocel-treated patients, compared with 24 (52.2% ) of 46, 20 (43.5 %) of 46, and 21 (45.7 %) of 46 control subjects, respectively. In patients with clinical remission at week 52, this remission was sustained at 104 and 156 weeks after treatment in 19 (65.5 %) of 29 and 16 (55.2 %) of 29 darvadstrocel-treated patients and in 17 (70.8 %) of 24 and 13 (54.2 %) of 24 control subjects, respectively. Time to fistula relapse and incidence of fistula relapse or new fistula occurrence were not significantly different between groups. Tumorigenicity was reported for 1 (2.2 %) patient in the control group (malignant epidermoid carcinoma). No ectopic tissue formation was reported. The authors concluded that real-world follow-up of patients from the ADMIRE-CD trial indicated that clinical remission of CPFs could be sustained in the long-term irrespective of whether it was achieved via darvadstrocel administration or maintenance treatment regimens and confirmed a favorable long-term safety profile of darvadstrocel. These researchers stated that darvadstrocel may represent an effective minimally invasive option to achieve long-term remission of CPFs in patients with CD. The authors stated that this study had several drawbacks, including small patient numbers. Potential bias may arise from the fact that the patient population in this chart review included only those who completed at least 52 weeks of follow-up in the ADMIRE-CD trial; however, the demographic profile and clinical characteristics of patients included in the INSPECT chart review were similar to that of the whole ITT population in the ADMIRE-CD trial. Furthermore, because some patients in this study completed only 52 weeks, whereas others completed up to 104 weeks in the ADMIRE-CD trial, the proportion of time spent enrolled in the phase-III ADMIRE-CD Trial versus the time enrolled in the INSPECT chart review varied. Consequently, certain outcomes may have been influenced by time spent in the ADMIRE-CD Trial. This drawback was partly mitigated by the fact that treatment in the ADMIRE-CD Trial was a single administration of darvadstrocel or placebo at the start of the study and that, after treatment, all patients continued with concomitant therapies and management of complex perianal fistulas (real-world management of complex perianal fistulas was maintained throughout the INSPECT study). A comparison of the sustained remission outcomes between groups at 156 weeks could also be biased because fewer patients in the control group achieved clinical remission than in the darvadstrocel group, hence unidentified confounders in these patient groups may influence the long-term remission outcomes. Analyses of subgroups to examine clinical outcomes by baseline patient and disease characteristics or concomitant medication could minimize the risk of bias; however, small sample sizes prohibited such comparisons. Finally, an inherent limitation of chart reviews was that datasets could be incomplete, preventing robust comparisons across all outcomes. In the INSPECT Trial, data were collected at the original ADMIRE-CD Trial sites, but some patients were followed-up at a different site to where they were enrolled, which could have contributed to the missing data.
